Is this a paragraph?
<p></p>		 Yes,
all of the text between <p> and </p> is a paragraph element.
Is this a paragraph element?
<p>My favorite color is green.</p>		 Yes,
all of the text between <p> and </p> is one paragraph.
Is this a paragraph element?
<p>		 No,
<p> is just the start tag.
Is this a paragraph element?
</p>		 No,
</p> is just the end tag.
How many paragraphs?
<p>Hello!</p><p>World!</p>		 2
Which word is emphasized?
<p>Hello! <em>World</em>!</p>		 World
How many paragraphs?
<p>Hello! <em>World</em>!</p>		 1
Which word is strong?
<p><strong>Hello</strong> <em>World</em>!</p>		 Hello
How many elements?
<p><strong>Hello</strong> <em>World</em>!</p>		 3
Can you write?
<p><strong>Hello<em> </strong> World</em>!</p>		 No,
elements cannot overlap.
How does this appear?
<p><strong>Hello</strong> <em>World</em>!</p>

Hello World!
Can you write?
<p><strong>Hello</strong> <br> <em>World</em>!</p>		 Yes,
some elements only have a start tag and not an end tag, and br is one such element.
How does this appear?
<p><strong>Hello</strong> <br> <em>World</em>!</p>

Hello
World!
How does this appear?
 <p>  <strong> Hello  </strong>
  <br> <em>World</em>!  </p>

Hello
World!
How does this appear?
<p>
<strong>
Hello
</strong>
<br>
<em>
World</em>!
</p>

Hello
World!
How does this appear?
 <p>  <strong>
       Hello  </strong>
  <br> 
     <em>World</em>!  </p>

Hello
World!


The amount of whitespace between elements and words doesn't matter (most of the time).
How does this appear?
<p>
<strong> Hello </strong>
<br>
<em> World</em> !  </p>

Hello
World !


Yes, there is a space between World and the exclamation point.

The Rules of Elements

(preliminary)

Elements nest, they do not overlap.

Whitespace doesn't matter (most of the time).

The Law of Markup

(preliminary)

Markup what you mean.

What is:
<abbr title="Department of 
Transportation">DOT</abbr>
 DOT

Make sure to hover your mouse over the "DOT".
What is:
<abbr title="HyperText 
Markup Language">HTML</abbr>
 HTML
What is:
<abbr title="Red, Orange, Yellow, 
Green, Blue, Indigo, Violet; 
the order of colors in a rainbow">
ROYGBIV</abbr>
 ROYGBIV
In your own words describe the abbr element. Here are my words:

The abbr element represents and abbreviation or acronym.
In:
<abbr title="Department of 
Transportation">DOT</abbr>

What is title? 		The title is an attribute.
In:
<abbr title="Department of 
Transportation">DOT</abbr>

What is the value of title? 		Department of Transportation
Is this a valid title attribute?
<abbr>DOT</abbr title="Department 
of Transportation">
 No,
attributes can only appear in the start tag.
Is this a valid title attribute?
<abbr title='Department 
of Transportation'> DOT </abbr >
 Yes,
the value of an attribute can be enclosed in either single or double quotes.
Is this a valid title attribute?
<abbr 
  title=Internationalization> 
  i18n </abbr >
 Yes,
the value of an attribute doesn't need to be enclosed in any quotes, as long as there are no special characters in the value.

We will define 'special' a bit later.
Are these valid title attributes?
<abbr 
  title=Internationalization
  title=Internationalized> 
  i18n </abbr >
 No,
firstly because i18n stands for Internationalization, not Internationalized, and secondly because you can only have one of any attribute per element.

Only the first one counts.
Describe in your own words what a title attribute on an abbr element contains. My own words:

The title contains the expansion of the acronym or abbreviation.
How do you make an abbreviation BnB that has an expansion of "Bed & Breakfast"? You aren't expected to be able to answer this yet, it depends on 'special' characters, which we haven't covered yet.
How do you make a list? 
<ol>
    <li> milk </li> 
    <li> bread </li>
</ol>
How does this list appear?
<ol>
    <li> milk </li> 
    <li> bread </li>
</ol>
  1. milk
  2. bread
What does <ol> mean? Begin an ordered list.
What does <li> mean? Begin an item in a list.
How does this list appear?
<ol>
    <li> milk </li> 
    <li> <strong>bread</strong> </li>
    <li> toothpaste </li> 
</ol>
  1. milk
  2. bread
  3. toothpaste
If <ol> begins an ordered list, what does <ul> do? Begin an unordered list.
How do you make an unordered list? 
<ul>
    <li> milk </li> 
    <li> bread </li>
</ul>
How does this list appear?
<ul>
    <li> milk </li> 
    <li> bread </li>
</ul>
  • milk
  • bread
Does the first item in this list have a valid id?
<ul>
    <li id='123z'> milk </li> 
    <li> bread </li>
</ul>
 No,
the value of an id must not start with a number.
Does the first item in this list have a valid id?
<ul>
    <li id='foo'> milk </li> 
    <li> bread </li>
</ul>
 Yes,
the value of an id must not start with a number.
Does the second item in this list have a valid id?
<ul>
    <li id='foo'> milk </li> 
    <li id='foo'> bread </li>
</ul>
 No,
the value of an id must be unique.
Does the second item in this list have a valid id?
<ul>
    <li id='foo'> milk </li> 
    <li id='bar'> bread </li>
</ul>
 Yes,
the value of an id must be unique.
Is 'id' an attribute?
<li id='foo'> milk </li> 		Yes,
attributes appear in the start tag of an element.
Is 'id' an attribute?
<li> milk </li id='foo'> 		No,
attributes appear in the start tag of an element.
Is 'id' a valid id attribute?
<li id='f o o'> milk </li> 		No,
the value of an id attribute must not contain any whitespace.
